groups.title: Lease Types & Structures
groups.shortDescription: FMV, $1 Out, TELP, and bundled leases—when and why to use each.
groups.tooltip: Quick reference for the most common lease structures.

modal.heading: Lease Types & Structures
modal.intro: Use this as a quick script to help reps position the right lease for the right customer outcome.

bullets.label: FMV Lease
bullets.body: Flexible term with options to return, upgrade, buy at fair value, or continue month-to-month—typically with lower payments.

bullets.label: $1 Out Lease
bullets.body: Customer ends with ownership for a nominal amount, typically in exchange for higher monthly payments.

bullets.label: Tax-Exempt Lease Purchase (TELP/Muni)
bullets.body: Designed for qualifying public sector entities; behaves like financing but includes tax-exempt advantages and ownership at term end.

bullets.label: Bundled Lease
bullets.body: Hardware, service, and sometimes supplies rolled into one predictable payment, reducing line-item shopping.

groups.title: End-of-Lease Transactions
groups.shortDescription: Upgrade, buyout, and return options—how to retain and grow accounts.

modal.heading: End-of-Lease Transactions
modal.intro: These are the main paths customers can take as they approach lease maturity.

bullets.label: Upgrade
bullets.body: Replace current devices with newer KM technology while maintaining the relationship and improving the solution.

bullets.label: Upgrade to Keep
bullets.body: Customer keeps selected equipment and adds new devices; kept units may require a buyout or residual payment.

bullets.label: Upgrade to Return
bullets.body: Customer returns existing devices and begins a new lease on the replacement fleet.

bullets.label: Buyout Options
bullets.body: Allows customers to purchase leased equipment outright based on remaining obligation and residual terms.

groups.title: Key Financial Concepts
groups.shortDescription: Rate factors, residuals, funding amount, and other core leasing numbers.
groups.tooltip: Essential financial components of every lease.

modal.heading: Key Financial Concepts
modal.intro: Anchor reps on the financial levers that shape monthly payments and customer approvals.

bullets.label: Lease Rate Factor
bullets.body: Multiplier used to estimate monthly payments from the financed amount.

bullets.label: Residual Value
bullets.body: Anticipated value of equipment at lease end, allowing lower payments on FMV structures.

bullets.label: Funding Amount
bullets.body: Total value financed, including equipment and any approved soft costs.

bullets.label: Credit Decision Inputs
bullets.body: Time in business, credit history, customer financials, structure, and past performance all influence approvals.

groups.title: Important Documents & Processes
groups.shortDescription: Master agreements, LOIs, funding packages, and key checkpoints.
groups.tooltip: Documents and workflows reps should recognize.

modal.heading: Important Documents & Processes
modal.intro: These documents and steps appear in nearly every leased deal. Reps don’t need to own the process—but they should recognize the terms.

bullets.label: Master Lease Agreement
bullets.body: Defines core terms and conditions applying across multiple schedules.

bullets.label: Schedules and Addenda
bullets.body: Specify equipment, locations, and special conditions for each unique transaction.

bullets.label: Letter of Intent / End-of-Term Notice
bullets.body: Captures the customer's formal decision as the lease approaches maturity.

bullets.label: Funding Package (KIT)
bullets.body: Complete set of required documents that allow KMPF to ship and fund the deal.

groups.title: Tools & Systems
groups.shortDescription: CPQ, MyKM, billing tools, customer portals, and DFS.
groups.tooltip: Where to go to structure and support leased deals.

modal.heading: Tools & Systems
modal.intro: Quick orientation to where reps go to structure, price, and support leased deals.

bullets.label: CPQ / Quoting Tools
bullets.body: Used to build configurations, set pricing, and generate lease documentation.

bullets.label: MyKM & Sales Portals
bullets.body: Access to rate cards, programs, promotions, and policy updates.

bullets.label: Billing & Customer Portals
bullets.body: Customers view invoices, balances, payment history, and account status.

bullets.label: DFS & Funding Reports
bullets.body: Summaries showing how each lease has been structured and funded.

groups.title: Customer Requirements & Compliance
groups.shortDescription: Insurance, tax documentation, disclosure states, and legal naming.
groups.tooltip: Items that affect how quickly a deal can fund.

modal.heading: Customer Requirements & Compliance
modal.intro: These requirements often determine how quickly a deal can move from approved to funded.

bullets.label: Insurance
bullets.body: Evidence of equipment coverage with correct loss payee information.

bullets.label: Tax-Exempt Certificates
bullets.body: Documentation needed from eligible customers for proper billing.

bullets.label: Disclosure States
bullets.body: States requiring additional interest or lender information on lease documents.

bullets.label: Accurate Legal Names
bullets.body: Customer entity names must match exactly across CPQ, contracts, and all supporting documents.

groups.title: Tax Advantages
groups.shortDescription: Section 179 concepts and how leasing may fit into a customer’s tax strategy.

modal.heading: Tax Advantages
modal.intro: Reps should never give tax advice, but these are key concepts to reference appropriately.

bullets.label: Section 179 Concept
bullets.body: Customers may be able to expense qualifying capital purchases in the year of acquisition.

bullets.label: Leasing vs. Buying
bullets.body: Lease payments may receive different tax treatment than equipment purchases; customers must consult advisors.

bullets.label: Positioning
bullets.body: Reps can introduce the concept but should encourage customers to speak with a tax professional.

groups.title: Sales Support
groups.shortDescription: Who reps can call for help: Leasing Ops, DCM, KMPF specialists, and learning tools.
groups.tooltip: You’re never alone on a leasing deal.

modal.heading: Sales Support
modal.intro: Reps never need to navigate complex leasing conversations alone—these are the teams who support them.

bullets.label: Leasing Operations
bullets.body: Support for documentation, funding status, requests, and lease processing.

bullets.label: DCM / Direct Channel Marketing
bullets.body: Promotion updates, program support, and campaign-specific pricing.

bullets.label: KMPF Specialists
bullets.body: Experts who can join customer calls, assist with deal structuring, and coach reps.

bullets.label: Learning Assets
bullets.body: Referrals back to the Playbook, Sales Process Guide, and conversation training tools.
